The Eurovision Song Contest is just around the corner and this year, it's taking place in Malmo, Sweden.

You can find out all about the event right here.

The UK's entry for 2024 is Olly Alexander who'll be performing his song, Dizzy.

But how's he feeling ahead of the big night, where he'll perform in front of 200 million people!

The Eurovision Song contest Grand Final will be shown on BBC One and iPlayer on Saturday 11 May.

The Eurovision Song contest Grand Final will be shown on BBC One and iPlayer on Saturday 11 May.

De-Graft and Olly Alexander

De-Graft: Olly, welcome to the show.

Olly: Thanks for having me!

D-G: You're going to be representing the UK in this year's Eurovision Song Contest. How does that feel?

OA: It's amazing. I'm really excited about it and I can't wait to get out there and perform.

D-G: What can you tell us about your song?

OA: It's called "Dizzy" and it's a really fun song. I wrote it with a few friends and we just had a lot of fun with it.

D-G: What was the inspiration behind the song?

OA: We were just messing around in the studio one day and this melody just kind of popped out. We all thought it was really catchy so we decided to turn it into a song.

D-G: How have you been preparing for the competition?

OA: I've been rehearsing a lot and I've been working with a great team of people who are helping me to put together an amazing show.

D-G: What are you most looking forward to about Eurovision?

OA: I'm really looking forward to getting out there and performing in front of such a huge audience. It's going to be an amazing experience.

D-G: Are you nervous at all?

OA: Not really, no. I'm just really excited. I can't wait to get out there and show everyone what I can do.

D-G: What do you think your chances are of winning?

OA: I don't know. I'm just going to go out there and do my best. I'm not really thinking about the competition too much. I'm just focusing on having a good time and putting on a great show.

D-G: Good luck with that, Olly!

OA: Thanks!

The night was dark and the air was cold. It was the perfect time for a good old-fashioned ghost story. The campers were gathered around the fire, and the night was filled with the sounds of crickets chirping and the crackling of the flames.
"Tell us a story, Uncle Bob!" one of the campers shouted.
Uncle Bob smiled. He loved telling stories, and he had just the one in mind.
"Once upon a time, there was a young boy named Jack who lived in a small village. Jack was always getting into trouble, and his parents were constantly worried about him.
One day, Jack was out exploring in the woods when he stumbled upon a mysterious cave. Inside the cave, he found a treasure chest filled with gold coins and precious gems.
Jack was thrilled, but he knew that he couldn't keep the treasure for himself. So he went back to the village and shared it with everyone.
The villagers were overjoyed, and they celebrated with a big feast. But that night, as Jack was sleeping in his bed, he heard a strange noise coming from the woods.
He got up to investigate, and he saw a giant bear standing outside his window. The bear was huge and menacing, and it stared at Jack with its cold, dead eyes.
Jack was terrified, but he knew that he had to be brave. He grabbed a stick and charged at the bear, shouting as loudly as he could.
The bear was startled, and it ran away into the woods. Jack was relieved, but he knew that he had to be more careful in the future.
From that day on, Jack was always on the lookout for danger. He became a brave and resourceful young man, and he went on to have many adventures.
And that's the story of Jack and the treasure chest.

The moon was high in the sky, casting a soft glow over the dark forest. The air was warm and humid, with a gentle breeze rustling through the trees. It was the perfect time for a spooky story.

A group of friends had gathered around a crackling campfire, huddled close together for warmth and comfort. They were sharing stories of their favorite horror movies, trying to outdo each other with their knowledge of the most terrifying monsters and jump scares.

As the night wore on, one of the friends, a girl named Sarah, suggested that they tell ghost stories instead. The others were hesitant at first, but eventually they agreed.

Sarah began the story, her voice low and steady as she spun a tale of a haunted cabin deep in the woods. As she spoke, the others leaned in closer, their eyes wide and their faces pale in the firelight.

The story unfolded, weaving a web of suspense and terror that left the group breathless and on the edge of their seats. They were all transfixed, unable to look away even as they shivered with fear.

Finally, Sarah finished the story, her voice trembling with emotion. The others were silent for a moment, their minds racing with the images and sounds of the story.

Then, suddenly, a loud crash came from somewhere in the woods. The friends jumped, their hearts pounding in their chests. They looked around nervously, trying to see if anything was out there.

But there was nothing. The forest was still, the night quiet except for the occasional hoot of an owl.

The friends breathed a sigh of relief, but they were still shaken. They exchanged nervous glances, their eyes wide and their faces pale in the firelight.

As they tried to calm themselves, another noise came from the woods. This time, it sounded like footsteps, slow and heavy, coming closer and closer.

The friends froze, their eyes fixed on the darkness beyond the firelight. They could feel their hearts beating faster, their breath coming in short, sharp gasps.

Finally, the footsteps stopped. The friends waited, their bodies tense and their minds racing.

And then, suddenly, a figure emerged from the shadows. The friends let out a collective gasp, their eyes wide with fear.

But as the figure stepped into the firelight, they realized it was just one of their friends, trying to scare them. They laughed nervously, their relief palpable.

But their laughter was cut short by another noise, this time from behind them. They whirled around, their hearts pounding in their chests.

And that's when they saw it. A giant dragon, towering over them, its eyes cold and dead.

The friends screamed, their voices echoing through the forest. They scrambled to their feet, trying to run, but the dragon was too fast. It grabbed one of them, its claws digging into his skin.

The others watched in horror as the dragon lifted their friend into the air, his screams piercing the night. Then, with a flick of its tail, the dragon tossed him into the fire.

The others tried to run, but they were too late. The dragon was on them, its claws and teeth tearing at their flesh. They screamed and cried, their blood staining the ground red.

And that's the story of the friends and the giant dragon. But that's not the end of the story.

The dragon continued to terrorize the forest, its hunger insatiable. It ate everything in its path, leaving behind a trail of destruction and death.

The villagers were terrified, huddled in their homes, praying for a savior. But no one came to their aid.

Finally, a young boy named Jack decided to take matters into his own hands. He had heard stories of the dragon's destruction, and he knew he had to do something.

He gathered his courage and set out into the forest, determined to find the dragon and slay it. But he was no match for the dragon's strength and ferocity.

The dragon grabbed Jack and lifted him into the air, its eyes cold and dead. Jack knew he was about to meet the same fate as his friends.

But then, something unexpected happened. Jack closed his eyes and made a wish. He wished for the dragon to be gone, to never terrorize the forest again.

And, miraculously, the dragon vanished, its body dissolving into a cloud of smoke. Jack was left standing there, alone and unharmed.

The villagers were overjoyed, celebrating with a big feast. But Jack knew that he had to be more careful in the future. He knew that he had faced the dragon once, but he could never be sure that it wouldn't return.

And so Jack went on to become a brave and resourceful young man, always on the lookout for danger. He faced many challenges and obstacles, but he always remembered the lessons he learned from the giant dragon.

And that's the story of the friends and the giant dragon, and the adventures that followed.

The friends jumped, their hearts pounding in their chests. They looked around nervously, trying to see if anything was out there. But there was nothing. The dragon was still, the day quiet except for the occasional bird call. The friends breathed a sigh of relief, but they were still shaken. They exchanged nervous glances, their eyes wide and their faces pale in the sunlight. As they tried to calm themselves, another noise came from the trees. This time, it sounded like footsteps, slow and heavy, coming closer and closer. The friends froze, their eyes fixed on the trees beyond the trail. They could feel their hearts beating faster, their breath coming in short, sharp gasps. Finally, the footsteps stopped. The friends waited, their bodies tense and their minds racing. And then, suddenly, a figure emerged from the shadows. The friends let out a collective gasp, their eyes wide with fear. But as the figure stepped into the sunlight, they realized it was just one of their friends, trying to scare them. They laughed nervously, their relief palpable. But their laughter was cut short by another noise, this time from behind them. They whirled around, their hearts pounding in their chests. And that's when they saw it. The giant dragon, towering over them, its eyes cold and dead. The friends screamed, their voices echoing through the forest. They scrambled to their feet, trying to run, but the dragon was too fast. It grabbed one of them, its claws digging into his skin. The others watched in horror as the dragon lifted their friend into the air, his screams piercing the day. Then, with a flick of its tail, the dragon tossed him into the trees. The others tried to run, but they were too late. The dragon was on them, its claws and teeth tearing at their flesh. They screamed and cried, their blood staining the ground red. And that's the story of the friends and the giant dragon. But that's not the end of the story. The dragon continued to terrorize the countryside, its hunger insatiable. It ate everything in its path, leaving behind a trail of destruction and death. The villagers were terrified, huddled in their homes, praying for a savior. But no one came to their aid. Finally, a young boy named Jack decided to take matters into his own hands. He had heard stories of the dragon's destruction, and he knew he had to do something. He gathered his courage and set out into the countryside, determined to find the dragon and slay it. But he was no match for the dragon's strength and ferocity. The dragon grabbed Jack and lifted him into the air, its eyes cold and dead. Jack knew he was about to meet the same fate as his friends. But then, something unexpected happened. Jack closed his eyes and made a wish. He wished for the dragon to be gone, to never terrorize the countryside again. And, miraculously, the dragon vanished, its body dissolving into a cloud of smoke. Jack was left standing there, alone and unharmed. The villagers were overjoyed, celebrating with a big feast. But Jack knew that he had to be more careful in the future. He knew that he had faced the dragon once, but he could never be sure that it wouldn't return. And so Jack went on to become a brave and resourceful young man, always on the lookout for danger. He faced many challenges and obstacles, but he always remembered the lessons he learned from the giant dragon. And that's the story of the friends and the giant dragon, and the adventures that followed.
